Description:
You come to a large sculpture of a heron's head. Next to it are two stone tablets that tell the history of the herons.

As you read, the herons were one of the first inhabitants of the desert and served Basthet for a long time.

After Basthet's paladin returned from the war against the Archons, Basthet decided to punish her for breaking her oath and the herons were in charge of burying her alive and sealing her in the northern pyramids.
DescriptionAction: The story continues in the next tablet but it is broken and you would have to rebuild it to continue.

    "SSRewardText": "With Laia's help, you manage to assemble the pieces according to how the tale should continue. \r\n\nA few years after punishing the paladin, the herons began to question whether they had done the right thing. From their perspective, she had done the right thing by fighting against the Archons. So, the herons appealed to Basthet, asking for mercy for the paladin. However, their only response was losing Basthet's favor, and they eventually abandoned the oasis in the southern desert. \r\n\nLaia tells you that instead of admiring the courage the herons showed in questioning their benefactor, you should learn that Basthet's will is not to be questioned.",

    "SSRewardText": "(Nenukil): “The key is to focus on the edges of the slabs. Start by filling in the ones on the borders, working from the outer edges toward the center. See? Here you can read the story.”\r\n\nA few years after punishing the paladin, the herons began to question whether they had made the right decision. From their perspective, she had done the right thing by fighting against the Archons. So, the herons appealed to Basthet, asking for mercy for the paladin. However, their only response was losing Basthet's favor, leading them to eventually abandon the oasis in the southern desert.\r\n\nNenukil is not impressed with their story, but you find the herons' courage in questioning their benefactor to be inspiring.",
